A standard serve is about 75g (100–350kJ) or:

- 1/2 cup cooked green or orange vegetables
 - 1/2 cup cooked dried or canned beans, peas or lentils
 - 1 cup green leafy or raw salad vegetables
 - 1/2 cup sweet corn
 - 1/2 medium potato or other starchy vegetables
 - 1 medium tomato

A standard serve is about 150g (350kJ) or:

- 1 medium apple, banana, orange or pear
 - 2 small apricots, kiwi fruits or plums
 - 1 cup diced or canned fruit
 Or only occasionally:

- 125ml (½ cup) fruit juice
 - 30g dried fruit

A standard serve is (500kJ) or:

- 1 slice (40g) bread
 - 1/2 medium (40g) roll or flat bread
 - 1/2 cup (75-120g) cooked rice, pasta, noodles, barley, buckwheat, semolina, polenta, bulgur or quinoa
 - 1/2 cup (120g) cooked porridge
 - 2/3 cup (30g) wheat cereal flakes
 - 1/4 cup (30g) muesli
 - 3 (35g) crispbreads
 - 1 (60g) crumpet
 - 1 small (35g) English muffin or scone

A standard serve is (500–600kJ):

- 65g cooked lean red meats (about 90-100g raw)
 - 80g cooked lean poultry (100g raw)
 - 100g cooked fish fillet (about 115g raw) or one small can of fish
 - 2 large (120g) eggs
 - 1 cup (150g) cooked or canned legumes/beans such as lentils, chick peas or split peas
 - 170g tofu
 - 30g nuts, seeds, peanut or almond butter or tahini or other nut or seed paste

A standard serve is (500–600kJ):

- 2 large (120g) eggs
 - 1 cup (150g) cooked or canned legumes/beans such as lentils, chick peas or split peas
 - 170g tofu
 - 30g nuts, seeds, peanut or almond butter or tahini or other nut or seed paste
 When choosing a meat free alternative, make sure to consult a dietitian, and consider the protein and iron levels in your diet

A standard serve is (500–600kJ):

- 1 cup (150g) cooked or canned legumes/beans such as lentils, chick peas or split peas
 - 170g tofu
 - 30g nuts, seeds, peanut or almond butter or tahini or other nut or seed paste
 When choosing a meat free alternative, make sure to consult a dietitian, and consider the protein and iron levels in your diet

A standard serve is (500–600kJ):

- 1 cup (250ml) fresh, UHT long life, reconstituted powdered milk or buttermilk
 - 1/2 cup (120ml) evaporated milk
 - 2 slices (40g) or 4 x 3 x 2cm cube (40g) of hard cheese, such as cheddar
 - 1/2 cup (120g) ricotta cheese
 - 3/4 cup (200g) yoghurt

A standard serve is (500–600kJ):
 - 1 cup (250ml) soy, rice or other cereal drink with at least 100mg of added calcium per 100ml
 - 100g almonds with skin
 - 60g sardines, canned in water
 - 1/2 cup (100g) canned pink salmon with bones
 - 100g firm tofu (check the label as calcium levels vary)
 When choosing a dairy free alternative, make sure to consult a dietitian, and consider the calcium levels in your diet

An excess serve is a serve of anything that doesn't provide nutritional value from any of the other 5 food groups for example:
 - a handful of lollies
 - a small cup of dipping sauce
 - a layer of spread on toast

A serve of a water based drink is one glass, or approximately 250mL. Most drinks are water based, for example:
 - a glass of spring water
 - a glass of soft drink or soda
 - a bottle of beer

A serve of milk or other dairy drinks is generally one glass, or approximately 250mL. for example:
 - a glass of skim milk
 - a glass of almond milk
 - half a glass of evaporated milk

A serve of caffeine is about 95mg. The amount of caffeine in a given drink varies wildly, but a serve is approximately:
 - a shot of espresso
 - one cup (250ml) of coffee
 - approximately four cans of cola
 - one regular strength energy drink

One standard drink of alcohol is equal to the percentage of alcohol, times the volume in litres, times 0.789.\n Either set the standards directly, or use the percentage slider to calculate the standards.
